title-group.article-title: Wave propagation in sandwich structures with resonators and periodic cores

abstract.p: Wave propagation in sandwich structures containing periodic cores and local resonators are studied. The effect on wave attenuation is emphasized. It is found that within certain frequency bands wave is forbidden from propagating through the structure with periodic cores or with resonators. It is also found that for the structure consisting of two different core materials periodically placed along the beam length, the location and range of the stop band can be tailored by the physical properties of the core. Also, with fixed core properties, the lattice constant becomes an important factor in controlling the location of the stop band. Moreover, the coupling of the two mechanisms can effectively enlarge the width of the stop band and enhance wave attenuation. It is evident that resonators are easier to use for filtering disturbances with low frequencies.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The investigation of the dynamic behavior in periodic structures has been a subject of extensive research for decades. The significance of the studies can be comprehended from the prime examples of engineering structures which feature periodic characteristics, such as multi-span bridges and layered composite systems. Past studies of layered media [1,2] showed that a periodically layered medium consisting of two different elastic materials is capable of attenuating waves of certain frequencies. The attenuation effect of wave propagation can be tailored by manipulating the mechanical properties of the two constituent layers and the ratio of layer thickness. The work done by Mead [3–5] showed that periodic structural assemblies also can produce a mechanism to give rise to wave attenuation. Such attenuation results from the proper interaction between the incident, reflected, and transmitted waves at the discontinuity. It was shown that a group of sinusoidal waves only propagate energy in certain frequency bands. Outside these bands, the wave motion decays with distance. Following Mead’s work, Ruzzene et al. [6] applied the concept of periodic constructions to a sandwich plate. They found that negative Poisson’s ratio (auxetic) core materials of different geometries placed periodically in the plate behave as directional filters. With the proper impedance mismatch, the propagation of waves over specified frequency bands can be obstructed. Later, Ruzzene and Tsopelas [7] investigated vibration and wave propagation characteristics of the sandwich plate with a honeycomb core. It was shown that the cell aspect ratio in the sandwich plate has a great impact on the location and the extent of the stop bands.

Another possibility of obstructing wave propagation in structures is to employ the unusual dynamic mechanism found in metamaterials that contain man-made microstructures with unusual properties which are not found in nature. Liu et al. [8] investigated a type of composite fabricated using lead balls coated with silicon rubber and embedded in an epoxy matrix. Near the local resonance frequencies, the composite behaves as a material with a negative effective mass density. Recently, Huang and Sun [9,10] established a theoretical foundation for the concept of negative effective mass occurring in metamaterials and showed that metamaterials are good candidates for filtering low-frequency stress waves. Later, the work of Chen et al. [11] showed that the concept of negative effective mass can be also used to interpret the dynamics of a sandwich structure with a core containing resonators.

In this study, analytical models are used to examine wave propagation in sandwich structures with periodic cores and with resonators. The effect of periodic core properties on stop bands and the coupling of resonators and periodic core mechanisms on wave attenuation are investigated. The Bloch theorem [12] is employed to analyze wave propagation in the periodic structure. Numerical examples are presented to illustrate the wave blocking behavior in the sandwich beams. The dispersion characteristics of sandwich structures containing resonators as well as periodic cores are also studied.

sec.title: Sandwich beam with periodic cores
sec.p:
Figure 1 displays the schematic of a sandwich beam with periodic core materials. A unit cell consisting of two sandwich units is exhibited in Figure 2(a) and can be regarded as a binary composite Timoshenko beam shown in Figure 2(b). The beam is composed of repetition of alternating section 1 with length a1 and section 2 with length a2. The lattice constant is denoted by a which equals to a1+a2. Two different core materials are used to construct the sections 1 and 2. The origin of the local coordinate is located at the junction. Figure 1.
A sandwich beam having periodic core property.
Figure 2.
The sketch of: (a) a unit cell and (b) its effective model.

The equations of motion governing deflections and rotations of sections 1 and 2 are given by (1)(GA)(r)[v″(r)(x,t)+ϕ'(r)(x,t)]-(ρA)(r)v··(r)(x,t)=0 (2)(EI)(r)ϕ″(r)(x,t)-(GA)(r)[v'(r)(x,t)+ϕ(r)(x,t)]-(ρI)(r)ϕ··(r)(x,t)=0 where r = 1, 2 for distinguishing section 1 from section 2, (EI)(r) denotes bending rigidity,(GA)(r) is shear rigidity, (ρA)(r) is mass per unit length, v(r)(x,t) is vertical displacement, ϕ(r)(x,t) is rotation of the cross-section of the sandwich beam, and x is the local coordinate. Since the bending rigidity depends only on the face sheet, EI is same for both sections. By assuming a general harmonic wave propagating in the sandwich beam, two displacement functions v and φ can be expressed in the wave form ei(qx-ωt)in which q is wave number and ω is angular frequency. Using the technique of separation of variables, displacement v(x,t) and rotation ϕ(x,t) can be further expressed as v∧(x)e-iωt and ϕ∧(x)e-iωt, respectively. Substituting these two displacement functions in equations (1) and (2) yields the general solutions of the form (3)v∧(r)(x)=D1(r)eik1(r)x+D2(r)eik2(r)x+D3(r)eik3(r)x+D4(r)eik4(r)x (4)ϕ∧(r)(x)=R1(r)eik1(r)x+R2(r)eik2(r)x+R3(r)eik3(r)x+R4(r)eik4(r)x, where Dl(r)are constant amplitudes and Rl(r)=Dl(r){(GA)(r)[kl(r)]2-(ρA)(r)ω2}/[i(GA)(r)kl(r)] for l=1,2,3,4. At the junction, the continuity of deflection, rotation, moment and shear force must be satisfied as follows (5)v∧(2)(0)=v∧(1)(0) (6)ϕ∧(2)(0)=ϕ∧(1)(0) (7)ϕ∧'(2)(0)=ϕ∧'(1)(0) (8)(GA)(2)[v∧'(2)(0)+ϕ∧(2)(0)]=(GA)(1)[v∧'(1)(0)+ϕ∧(1)(0)].

Moreover, the Bloch theorem [12] guarantees the displacement, rotation, moment, and shear force have a certain relationship, namely (9)v∧(2)(a2)=eiqav∧(1)(-a1) (10)ϕ∧(2)(a2)=eiqaϕ∧(1)(-a1) (11)ϕ∧'(2)(a2)=eiqaϕ∧'(1)(-a1) (12)(GA)(2)[v∧'(2)(a2)+ϕ∧(2)(a2)]=eiqa(GA)(1)[v∧'(1)(-a1)+ϕ∧(1)(-a1)]

The dispersion relationship can be obtained by solving equations (5) to (12) for wave number q for varying frequency ω. Depending on whether q is real or complex, the corresponding wave propagates through the sandwich beam (pass band) or is damped (stop band).

sec.title: Sandwich beam with local resonance structures
sec.p:
The schematic of the sandwich construction with a core that contains resonators is shown in Figure 3. Each resonator is contained in an elastic housing embedded in the core. For modeling purpose, an equivalent sandwich beam shown in Figure 4 is used. The effective sandwich beam is modelled as a Timoshenko beam having the bending rigidity EI and shear rigidity GA that are equivalent to the original sandwich beam but without resonators. Figure 3.
Sandwich beam with internal resonators.
Figure 4.
Schematic equivalent model.

According to the discussion in the previous section, the solution of the displacements of such a sandwich beam has a similar form given by in equations (3) and (4). However, in this case only one core material (core 1) is involved. Hence the displacement and rotation functions of the beam can be simply written as (13)v∧(x)=D1eik1x+D2eik2x+D3eik3x+D4eik4x (14)ϕ∧(x)=R1eik1x+R2eik2x+R3eik3x+R4eik4x, where Dl, l = 1,2,3,4, are amplitude coefficients and Rl=Dl{(GA)[kl]2-(ρA)ω2}/[i(GA)kl]. Also, the continuity conditions are satisfied automatically in this model. By virtue of Bloch theorem [12], the following relationships between the displacements, rotations, moments, and shear forces are obtained (15)v∧(a)=eiqav∧(0) (16)ϕ∧(a)=eiqaϕ∧(0) (17)ϕ∧'(a)=eiqaϕ∧'(0) (18)-(GA)[v∧'(a)+ϕ∧(a)]=eiqa{-(GA)[v∧'(0)+ϕ∧(0)]+f∧(0)} where f∧(0)=2k1[1-2k1/(2k1-m1ω2)]v∧(0). Solving equations (15) to (18) gives the dispersion relation for such a sandwich beam.

sec.title: Sandwich beam containing internal resonators and periodic cores
sec.p:
Consider an infinite sandwich beam having periodic cores and internal resonators, shown in Figure 5. The resonators are inserted at the junction of two cores periodically. Figure 6(a) and (b) depicts the unit cell and its equivalent model consisting of two effective Timoshenko beams with one spring-mass system. Figure 5.
Sandwich beam containing periodic cores and internal resonators.
Figure 6.
(a) A unit cell and (b) its equivalent model.

In this model, the equations of motion and the solutions of displacement functions for sections 1 and 2 can be still expressed as the forms displayed in equations (1) to (4). The continuity of displacement, rotation, shear forces, and bending moment gives (19)v∧(2)(0)=v∧(1)(0) (20)ϕ∧(2)(0)=ϕ∧(1)(0) (21)ϕ∧'(2)(0)=ϕ∧'(1)(0) (22)-(GA)(2)[v∧'(2)(0)+ϕ∧(2)(0)]+f∧(0)=-(GA)(1)[v∧'(1)(0)+ϕ∧(1)(0)]

Due to the periodicity of the structure in the x direction, the displacement, rotation, and moment have to satisfy the Bloch theorem [12] (23)v∧(2)(a2)=eiqav∧(1)(-a1) (24)ϕ∧(2)(a2)=eiqaϕ∧(1)(-a1) (25)ϕ∧'(2)(a2)=eiqaϕ∧'(1)(-a1) (26)(GA)(2)[v∧'(2)(a2)+ϕ∧(2)(a2)]=eiqa(GA)(1)[v∧'(1)(-a1)+ϕ∧(1)(-a1)] where f∧(0)=2k1[1-2k1/(2k1-m1ω2)]v∧(1)(0). Solving equations (19) to (26) yields the dispersion relation for such a sandwich beam.

sec.title: Effect of material properties on attenuation factor and stop bands in a sandwich beam with periodic cores
sec.p:
Table 1 lists the dimensions and material constants adopted in the computation, and the corresponding sandwich beam properties are listed in Table 2. The face sheets are [02/902/02] laminates made of AS43501-6 carbon/epoxy composite material. The laminate has an effective elastic Young’s modulus Ef; the core is Rohacell IG-51 foam with a shear modulus Gc. The thickness of the face sheet and that of the core are denoted by hf and hc, respectively, and the width of the beam is denoted by b. The densities of the face sheet and the core are 1550 and 52.1 kg/m3, respectively. Table 1.

Consider an infinitely long sandwich beam with a periodic foam core. The lattice constant is chosen to be a = 0.75 m, and a1=a2=0.375m. Five sandwich beams are selected in order to show the effect of shear rigidity and mass density on the dispersion curves. The material properties of core 1 are selected as the ones shown in Table 2. Table 3 summarizes the properties of these five beams. Figure 7(a) to (e) shows the dispersion curves for the five different sandwich beams, respectively. The α and β denote, respectively, the real part and imaginary part of the dimensionless wave number, namely q¯=qa=α+iβ. It is concluded that Beam III is more capable of enlarging the stop band and increasing the value of β than other three beams. In Figure 7(e), it is noted that the width of frequency in the stop bands becomes very narrow. That is, increasing the ratio of the shear rigidities of the two cores while decreasing that of the mass densities with the same proportion yields little effect on wave attenuation. The variation of the lower limit of the first bandgap with varying lattice constant is depicted in Figure 8. Beam I is taken as an example. The lattice constants are selected as 0.25, 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 m. It is found that a larger lattice constant can produce a lower frequency band. Table 3.

Figure 7.
Dispersion curves and bandgaps of: (a) Beam I, (b) Beam II, (c) Beam III, (d) Beam IV and (e) Beam V.
Figure 8.
Lower limit of the first bandgap with varying lattice constant.

The results in Figure 7 indicate that mass density or shear rigidity of the sandwich core can change the magnitude of β as well as modify the location and width of the stop bands. Hence, we further conduct an investigation in the effect of ρ2/ρ1 and that of (GA)2/(GA)1 on the maximum value of β and the gap width of stop bands in sandwich beams with periodic cores. We take the lattice constant to be 0.048 m, i.e. a1=a2=0.024m. Figure 9 exhibits the variation of βmax and the bandgap width for the first stop band with varying properties of the core. In Figure 9(a), the shear rigidities of the two cores are chosen to be identical, the ratio of mass density is assumed to be 2.5, 5.0, 7.5, 10.0, or 12.5. Conversely, in Figure 9(b), the densities of the two core materials are assumed identical, and the ratio (GA)2/(GA)1 varies from 2.5 to 12.5. In Figure 9(c), ρ2/ρ1 and (GA)2/(GA)1 are assumed to be equal and both vary from 2.5 to 12.5. It is found that the larger ratio ρ2/ρ1 or (GA)2/(GA)1 is taken, the larger βmax is obtained. It is also observed that among the three cases, the last one can give the largest βmax and the widest frequency gap. Figure 9.
Effect of the ratio ρ2/ρ1 or (GA)2/(GA)1 on βmax and the width of the first band gap.

sec.title: Dispersion curves of a sandwich beam containing internal resonators
sec.p:
An infinite sandwich beam with a homogenous core containing resonators as depicted in Figure 3 is considered. The dimensions and material moduli shown in Table 1 are used to perform the numerical computation. Table 4 lists the modified effective properties of the sandwich beam. A plastic casing is used to contain the resonator. The height of the casing is the same as the thickness of the foam core. The density of the casing is 2090kg/m3. The outer diameter and the thickness of the casing are 0.00635 m and 0.00081 m, respectively. The lattice constant of a unit cell is taken as 0.048 m. The spring constant k1 is chosen as 5415.74 N/m and m1as 1.17×10-3kg. Table 4.
Modified effective properties of the sandwich beam.
EI(Pa·m4) GA(Pa·m2) ρA(kg/m) ρI(kg·m)
677 2.0×104 0.0875 1.40×10-5

Figure 10 illustrates the dispersion curves of the sandwich beam with resonators. The normalized angular frequency is defined as ω¯=ω/ω0 where ω0=2k1/m1=484Hz is the local resonance frequency of the resonator, and α and β denote the real and imaginary parts of the dimensionless wave number q¯=qa. From Figure 10, it is seen that, when wave frequency approaches the local resonance frequency ω0, i.e. ω¯=1, the attenuation factor β becomes unbounded. The lower limit of the bandgap is seen to coincide with the local resonance frequency of the resonator. By tailoring the local resonance frequency of the resonator the desired frequency gap can be acquired. Figure 10.
The dispersion curves of the sandwich beam with resonators.

sec.title: Attenuation effect in sandwich structures with resonators and with periodic cores
sec.p:
Since both sandwich structures with resonators and with periodic cores are capable of blocking waves with certain frequencies from propagating into the beam, it is of interest to study the efficiencies in wave attenuation in these two types of sandwich structures. The total mass of the two beams is set equal. For the beam with a periodic core, the total mass represents the mass of the beam consisting of two face sheets and two cores whereas for the beam with resonators, the total mass includes not only the mass of the original beam but also the internal mass m1. Consider the unit cells of the two types of sandwich beams as shown in Figure 11. The unit length a is chosen as 0.048 m. The total mass varies with different ratios ρ2/ρ1 as discussed in Figure 9(a), but here the density ratios are taken as 5.0, 10.0, 15.0, and 20.0 instead. Figure 11.
Sandwich beam: (a) with periodic cores, (b) with resonators.

The local resonance frequency of resonators ω0 for the beam with resonators is selected to be the same as the optimized frequency ωc which produces the maximum attenuation factor β in the beam with periodic cores, i.e. ω0=ωc. Using the first band gap as an example, Figure 12(a) displays the variation of βr/βc ratio with varying wave frequency and total mass. The βr and βc denote the attenuation factors of the two sandwich beams, respectively, and ω¯=ω/ω0=ω/ωc. The Mt is the total mass of the sandwich beam in a unit cell and M0 is the mass of the original beam consisting of two sheets and core 1 only in a unit cell and is used as a reference mass here. It is seen that as ω¯→1, βr/βc becomes very large, and that even at a distance away from ω¯=1, the difference between the two decay factors remains quite substantial. In other words, resonators always provide much better efficiency in wave attenuation than periodic cores. In Figure 12(b), it is obvious that, for the beam with resonators, the bandgap width is proportional to the ratio of core mass densities. In contrast, for the beam with periodic cores, the gap width grows more slowly. It is found that increasing the ratio of densities of cores might not lead to a wider gap. It is also seen that resonators may make a greater impact on wave attenuation. Figure 12.
Comparison between two types of sandwich beams for: (a) β ratio, and (b) the gap width.

Figure 13 shows two types of sandwich beams; one has a section with 10 periodic core units and the other has a section with 2 resonators. Outside the section, no resonators/periodic cores are present. A prescribed displacement applied to the respective left ends of the two beams is given by (27)v(t)=v0sinωt t≥0 Figure 13.
(a) A sandwich beam with 10 periodic core units, and (b) a sandwich beam with 2 resonators.

The sandwich beam is modeled by planar Timoshenko beam elements with linear interpolation provided by the commercial code ABAQUS. For the resonator model, each beam element is assumed to possess the bending rigidity, shear rigidity, rotary inertia, and mass per unit length given in Table 4. The element size is 0.003 m, which is 1/16 of the length of the unit cell. The resonator is discretely attached to the beam element as depicted in Figure 4. For the periodic core model, a unit cell contains two types of Timoshenko beams possessing identical bending rigidity and shear rigidity shown in Table 4 but having different densities. The density ratio of two beams is taken as 20. Hence the ratio of Mt to Mo is 4.12. The total mass of the two beams is still set equal. For the purpose of comparison, the applied frequencies are chosen as 1.01ωc and 1.15ωc in which ωc=ω0. Figure 14(a) and (b) shows, respectively, the deformed shapes of the first 2 m of the sandwich beams after actuation begins. It is evident that for the beam with resonators, a sharp spatial decay of amplitude of the flexural motion takes place whereas for the beam with periodic cores, decay is much more gradual. Also, it is found that as the exciting frequency is closer to ωc, the attenuation effect is more conspicuous. It is also noted that fewer numbers of resonators can lead to the same results as a longer periodic core. Figure 14.
Wave profiles for two sandwich beams excited with a harmonic displacement having a dominant frequency: (a) ω=1.01ωc and (b) ω=1.15ωc.

sec.title: Dispersion relations for sandwich beams having both periodic cores and internal resonators
sec.p:
For simplicity, the weight of the casing here is not considered. By employing the parameters of the sandwich beam listed in Table 2, the dispersion characteristics of the sandwich beam containing resonators and periodic cores are acquired from equations (19) to (26) and shown in Figure 15. The lattice constant is taken as 0.75 m, i.e., a1=a2=0.375m. The spring constant k1 and the internal mass m1 are selected as 2.37×104 N/m and 0.05625kg, respectively. The density ratio and the ratio of the shear rigidity between two cores are chosen as 4.0. Figure 15(a) shows the β value for the beam with periodic cores but without resonators whereas Figure 15(b) to (d) displays β values for the beams with periodic cores and internal resonators. The local resonance frequencies of the resonators are taken as 350, 1075, and 1500 rad/s, respectively. In Figure 15(b), it is evident that if the resonance frequency of the resonator is below the first stop band, the bandgap generated by the periodic mechanism is not affected. However, if the resonance frequency is above or within the 1st stop band, the new first stop band is lowered as shown in Figure 15(c) and (d), and the magnitude of β somewhat increases. From the results displayed in Figure 15(c), it is noted that the coupling of two mechanisms can significantly enlarge the width of the bandgap produced by resonators. Figure 15.
Attenuation factor for the sandwich beam containing: (a) periodic cores only, (b) periodic cores and resonators with ω0=350rad/s, (c) periodic cores and resonators with ω0=1075rad/s, and (d) periodic cores and resonators with ω0=1500rad/s.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, theoretical models to analyze wave propagation in sandwich structures with periodic cores and resonators are presented. It is shown that sandwich beams with resonators embedded in the core or with periodic core properties can produce stop bands to forbid wave propagation. For the sandwich beam with periodic cores to obtain large bandgap widths, the ratio of densities and that of rigidities of the two core materials must have the same proportion. Also, a large lattice constant is needed to block the disturbances with low frequencies. It is also seen that the resonators are more efficient in producing wave attenuation and vibration reduction. The desired bandgap can be easily acquired by selecting the local resonance frequency of resonators. This is especially true for low frequency bandgaps. Furthermore, the coupling of the two mechanisms is able to effectively enlarge the width of bandgap and enhance wave attenuation.
